title: File Operations Basics
description: Fundamental concepts of file handling in Python.

cards.front: What function do you use to open a file in Python?
cards.back: The open() function. It takes a filename and mode as arguments and returns a file object.

cards.front: What are the common file modes in Python?
cards.back: 'r' for reading, 'w' for writing (overwrites), 'a' for appending, 'r+' for reading and writing.

cards.front: Why should you close files after using them?
cards.back: Closing files frees up system resources and ensures data is properly written to disk.

cards.front: What is the benefit of using 'with' statement for file operations?
cards.back: The 'with' statement automatically closes the file when you're done, even if an error occurs.

cards.front: What does the read() method return?
cards.back: The read() method returns the entire file content as a single string.

title: File Reading Methods
description: Different ways to read file content.

cards.back: readline() reads one line from the file and returns it as a string, including the newline character.
readlines() reads all lines from the file and returns them as a list of strings.

cards.front: How do you read a file line by line efficiently?
cards.back: Use a for loop: for line in file: - this reads one line at a time without loading the entire file into memory.

cards.front: What is the difference between read() and readlines()?
cards.back: read() returns the entire file as one string, readlines() returns a list where each element is a line.
